awd_titl_txt: Ecological Similitude and Scaling for Robust Modeling and Predictions of Ecosystem Carbon, Water and Energy Fluxes
awd_abstract_narration:
1705941 (Abdul-Aziz). The goal of this research is to discover the similitude patterns and scaling laws of ecosystem carbon, water and energy fluxes, and formulate robust models to predict the fluxes at variable time and space scales. The underlying hypothesis is that the ecosystem fluxes follow emergent ecological similitude and scaling laws, which will lead to robust estimation and predictive models. 

The specific research objectives are to (1) identify the dominant drivers and quantify the relative linkages of ecosystem carbon (CO2), latent heat (LE) and sensitive heat (H) fluxes with the relevant climatic, hydrologic and ecological variables at different time and space scales; (2) investigate similitude (parametric reductions), formulate meaningful dimensionless groups, and develop scaling laws (emergent patterns) for the ecosystem fluxes; and (3) formulate spatiotemporally robust empirical models for predicting the ecosystem fluxes from diverse ecosystems. The research will utilize the AmeriFlux data of fluxes, climate, environmental, and ecological variables for different time-scales (e.g., hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, yearly) and periods (e.g., 2000-2015) at numerous sites (above 100) across America, representing gradients of hydroclimatic, biogeochemical, and ecological processes. The research objectives will be achieved by conducting dimensional analysis and empirical modeling, which has successfully been applied in fluid mechanics, hydraulic engineering and stream ecology. The research builds on a previous project on wetland biogeochemical similitude and scaling to robustly predict wetland greenhouse gas fluxes by using chamber-based field data. This project will use flux tower-based eddy-covariance data (AmeriFlux) to generalize the similitude, scaling and robust modeling hypothesis across diverse ecosystems (e.g., deciduous forests, evergreen needleleaf forests, rain forests, grasslands, croplands, wetlands) at variable time (hour to year) and space (site, region, continent) scales. The research will promote environmental sustainability by contributing insights, understanding, and broad knowledge into the emergence (similarity and scaling) patterns of ecosystem carbon, water and energy fluxes. Robust, parsimonious models can be utilized as simple, scale-independent engineering tools to predict the ecosystem fluxes across a wide range of spatial and temporal scales. Research outcomes will be broadly disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, graduate dissertations, reports, YouTube videos, and an open-access project website. The research findings will be utilized to teach two interdisciplinary courses, Ecohydrological Engineering (undergraduate) and Ecological Engineering (graduate), using inductive learning methods. High school students and teachers will also be involved with the research through outreach activities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated the dominant controls of ecosystem greenhouse gas (GHG) fluxes, generated new mechanistic insights, and developed robust models to predict the GHG fluxes at variable time and space scales. Accordingly, the dominant environmental controls of the major ecosystem GHG fluxes (such as carbon dioxide and methane) were robustly determined at various timescales (hourly to monthly) and 50+ sites across the U.S. The sites incorporated different ecosystem types (e.g., wetlands, forests, croplands, grasslands), as well as gradients in hydro-climatic, biogeochemical, and ecological processes. The research then focused on the analytics, similitude, and robust predictions of the GHG fluxes in wetlands across the globe.

The research led to the discovery of scale-invariant patterns and emerging organizing principles, which helped develop generalized models to robustly predict the carbon fluxes in inland and coastal wetland ecosystems. The models can be leveraged as useful tools to promote environmental sustainability. The models were further represented as Excel-based user-friendly software for lay users. The developed models and research outcomes are expected to guide planning, restoration, monitoring, and adaptive management of wetland ecosystems under a changing climate and environment. The analytical/modeling framework and the concept of similitude (similarity) can be employed to identify emergent patterns, scaling principles, and models for reductions in GHG emissions from natural gas fields, transportation, and other industrial/commercial sectors.

The project had a significant impact on the development of human resources by training students with necessary knowledge, skills, and attitude for promoting environmental sustainability. Three doctoral and three master’s (thesis) students (all graduated) in Civil and Environmental Engineering were funded by the project. Among them, two PhD and two MS (thesis) students graduated during spring-summer of 2022. The third MS (thesis) and third PhD students graduated in 2023. The students were trained in professional developments with specialization in environmental data sciences, statistical analysis, pattern recognition techniques, data-driven and process-based modeling, geographic information system (GIS), and remote sensing under the broad umbrella of ecohydrological, environmental, and water resources engineering. They were also trained in data curation, data analysis, computer programming (in Excel, MATLAB, Python), simulations, and ecosystem carbon cycle processes. All the students subsequently landed high-end research and/or consulting careers in the U.S., contributing to the growth of U.S. economy.

The project activities at WVU (an EPSCoR institution) have promoted participation of economically disadvantaged groups and minorities in the U.S. The project engaged many graduate and undergraduate students, giving priority to the minority and female students. The research objectives, activities, and findings were shared during 2017 to 2023 with a large group of undergraduate and graduate students through numerous junior/senior level undergraduate and graduate classes. New curriculum materials through inductive learning-based pedagogies (e.g., case studies) were developed for the courses. Hands-on training on developing simple, spreadsheet-based models to predict ecosystem GHG fluxes was provided to the middle to high school students and teachers in Morgantown, WV and in Cape Cod, MA. They were trained in data curation, analysis, modeling and predictions, and ecosystem carbon cycle processes.

The findings were broadly disseminated through 16 presentations and 16 abstracts in respected international conferences. Additionally, four (4) invited talks were given by the PI (Abdul-Aziz): 1 in regional conference, 1 in estuarine research reserve workshop, and 2 in peer U.S. universities. Based on the project activities and findings, the PI also convened and chaired 22 well-attended sessions on wetland processes and carbon cycle in the American Geophysical Union’s Annual Fall Meetings, as well as in the American Society of Civil Engineer’s Annual Environmental & Water Resources Congresses, held during 2017-2023. Six (6) peer-reviewed journal articles were published, and four (4) additional journal manuscripts have been prepared based on the results from this project. The four pending manuscripts are expected to be published in the near future. Further, one YouTube video was published where the PI described the project activities, results, and robust models to scientists, engineers, and stakeholders at large. 

In summary, the project generated new knowledge and insights into the dominant controls of ecohydrological and biogeochemical processes in diverse ecosystems and provided scale-independent engineering tools and parsimonious models to robustly predict the major GHG fluxes of carbon dioxide and methane in wetland ecosystems. Research and education outcomes have broadly been disseminated to improve scientific and public knowledge for their effective participation in wetland carbon restoration, monitoring, and conservation programs. The project involved and trained many students—representing minority and disadvantaged communities in the U.S.—to meet the demand of critical expertise on environmental sustainability under a changing climate and environment. The scientific understanding and models/tools generated from this research can be leveraged to develop effective restoration, monitoring, management, and conservation guidelines for mitigating global warming/climate change and achieving environmental sustainability. This would also help engineers and managers achieve and maintain the beneficial ecosystem services from wetlands in the contiguous U.S. and beyond.

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2024
Modified by: Omar I Abdul-Aziz

    Omar I Abdul-Aziz
    The Characteristic Process Diagram of Carbon Dioxide Fluxes in Coastal Salt Marshes
  • Pearson�s correlation coefficients (r) between net uptake fluxes of carbon dioxide with the environmental drivers in diverse ecosystems. ENF, DBF, MF, CRO, GRA, and WET, refer to evergreen forest, deciduous forest, mixed forest, grassland, cropland, and wetland, respectively.
    Omar I. Abdul-Aziz
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Omar I Abdul-Aziz
    Climatic and Ecohydrological Controls of Ecosystem Carbon Dioxide Uptake Fluxes Vary Across Climatic Zones
  • Comparison between modeled and literature-reported CH4 emission fluxes across a wide range of salinity regimes and plant communities along the Atlantic, Gulf, and Pacific Coasts of USA and beyond (Canada, China, and Japan). NEE_CH4,emission = net emission fluxes of CH4; ST = soil temperature.
    Omar I. Abdul-Aziz
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Omar I Abdul-Aziz
    The 4/3 Power Scaling of Methane Emissions with Porewater Salinity in Coastal Salt Marshes

    Omar I. Abdul-Aziz

    Environmental Controls on Wetland Carbon Dioxide Uptake Fluxes Vary Across Climatic Zones

    Omar I. Abdul-Aziz
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Omar I Abdul-Aziz
    Environmental Controls on Wetland Methane Emission Fluxes Vary Across Climatic Zones

    Omar I. Abdul-Aziz
    Copyrighted
    Omar I Abdul-Aziz
    Machine Learning Models Do Not Predict Wetland GHG Fluxes Better Than Power Law Scaling Models
